author: _shemnon
content: My concern is if EOF bans dynamic initialization then the cases where it is used extensively would prevent us from sunsetting legacy EVM code segments, until EOF does support it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Are there use cases that require dynamic initialization that we want to continue supporting?  I don't mind ceasing support for something that can be achieved another way, or doesn't have any "reasonable" use cases.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, we don't currently have any EOL policies, which we would need if we wanted to remove *anything* from the EVM just about.

author: _shemnon
content: Disabling SELFDESTRUCT will prevent the typical polymorphic contract address usecase.  But I could see upgradable redemption contracts as an exotic defi primitive.  Send to an calculated address, then when you redeem the deposit the init code installs the latest "approved" contract at that address as determined by another contract.

author: _shemnon
content: Basically upgradable one-time-withdrawal scripts (not quite the paradox it seems)

author: gcolvin
content: Meaning there is a better engineered solution that doesn't need dynamic initialization?
